018package org.tquadrat.foundation.lang.internal;
019
020import static org.apiguardian.api.API.Status.DEPRECATED;
021import static org.apiguardian.api.API.Status.INTERNAL;
022
023import java.util.Formatter;
024import java.util.IllegalFormatException;
025import java.util.Locale;
026import java.util.function.Supplier;
027
028import org.apiguardian.api.API;
029import org.tquadrat.foundation.annotation.ClassVersion;
030import org.tquadrat.foundation.annotation.UtilityClass;
031import org.tquadrat.foundation.exception.PrivateConstructorForStaticClassCalledError;
032
033/**
034 *  This class provides an implementation of
035 *  {@link java.lang.String#format(Locale,String,Object...) String.format()}
036 *  that uses a shared instance of
037 *  {@link java.util.Formatter}.
038 *
039 *  @extauthor Thomas Thrien - thomas.thrien@tquadrat.org
040 *  @version $Id: SharedFormatter.java 1060 2023-09-24 19:21:40Z tquadrat $
041 *  @since 0.1.0
042 *
043 *  @UMLGraph.link
044 *
045 *  @deprecated Java 21 introduces Virtual Threads, and those invalidate any
046 *      enhancement that can be achieved by a cached
047 *      {@link Formatter}.
048 *      In addition, the introduction of
049 *      {@link String#formatted(Object...)}
050 *      provides an elegant API that is not usable with the cached
051 *      {@code Formatter} instance.
052 */
053@Deprecated( since = "0.3.0", forRemoval = true )
054@ClassVersion( sourceVersion = "$Id: SharedFormatter.java 1060 2023-09-24 19:21:40Z tquadrat $" )
055@API( status = DEPRECATED, since = "0.3.0" )
056@UtilityClass
057public final class SharedFormatter
058{
059        /*-----------*\
060    ====** Constants **========================================================
061        \*-----------*/
062    /**
063     *  The initial buffer size that is used by
064     *  {@link #format(String, Object...)}
065     *  and
066     *  {@link #format(Locale, String, Object...)}
067     *  (per thread): {@value}.
068     *
069     *  @since 0.1.0
070     */
071    @API( status = INTERNAL, since = "0.1.0" )
072    public static final int FORMAT_INITIAL_BUFFERSIZE = 2048;
073
074        /*------------------------*\
075    ====** Static Initialisations **===========================================
076        \*------------------------*/
077    /**
078     *  The cached
079     *  {@link Formatter}
080     *  instance.
081     */
082    private static final ThreadLocal<Formatter> m_Formatter;
083
084    static
085    {
086        //---* The cached Formatter instance *---------------------------------
087        final Supplier<Formatter> initializer = () -> new Formatter( new StringBuilder( FORMAT_INITIAL_BUFFERSIZE ), Locale.getDefault( Locale.Category.FORMAT ) );
088        //noinspection RedundantTypeArguments
089        m_Formatter = ThreadLocal.<Formatter>withInitial( initializer );
090    }
091
092        /*--------------*\
093    ====** Constructors **=====================================================
094        \*--------------*/
095    /**
096     *  No instance of this class is allowed.
097     */
098    private SharedFormatter() { throw new PrivateConstructorForStaticClassCalledError( SharedFormatter.class ); }
099
100        /*---------*\
101    ====** Methods **==========================================================
102        \*---------*/
103    /**
104     *  Returns a formatted String using the specified format String and
105     *  arguments.<br>
106     *  <br>The implementation uses internally the
107     *  {@link Locale}
108     *  that is returned by
109     *  {@link java.util.Locale#getDefault() Locale.getDefault()}.<br>
110     *  <br>This method is meant as a replacement for the method
111     *  {@link java.lang.String#format(String, Object...)};
112     *  that implementation always uses a new instance of
113     *  {@link Formatter}
114     *  for each invocation. The implementation here uses a cached instance
115     *  instead, and as {@code Formatter} is not inherently thread-safe, this
116     *  cached instance is created and stored per thread, therefore no
117     *  synchronisation is needed.<br>
118     *  <br>This implementation is about as twice as fast as
119     *  {@code java.lang.String.format()}.
120     *
121     *  @param  format  A format String with the syntax as described for the
122     *      {@link Formatter}
123     *      class.
124     *  @param  args    The arguments referenced by the format specifiers in
125     *      the {@code format} String. If there are more arguments than format
126     *      specifiers, the extra arguments are ignored. The number of
127     *      arguments is variable and may be zero. The maximum number of
128     *      arguments is limited by the maximum dimension of a Java array as
129     *      defined by <cite>The Java&trade; Virtual Machine
130     *      Specification</cite>. The behaviour on a {@code null} argument
131     *      depends on the conversion.
132     *  @throws IllegalFormatException A format string contains an illegal
133     *      syntax, a format specifier that is incompatible with the given
134     *      arguments, insufficient arguments given the format string, or other
135     *      illegal conditions occurred. For specification of all possible
136     *      formatting errors, see the &quot;Details&quot; section of the
137     *      {@code Formatter} class specification.
138     *  @return A formatted String.
139     *
140     *  @see  java.util.Formatter
141     *
142     *  @since 0.1.0
143     */
144    @API( status = INTERNAL, since = "0.1.0" )
145    public static final String format( final String format, final Object... args ) throws IllegalFormatException
146    {
147        return format( Locale.getDefault( Locale.Category.FORMAT ), format, args );
148    }   //  format()
149
150    /**
151     *  Returns a formatted String using the specified
152     *  {@link Locale},
153     *  format String, and arguments.<br>
154     *  <br>This method is meant as a replacement for the method
155     *  {@link java.lang.String#format(String, Object...)};
156     *  that implementation always uses a new instance of
157     *  {@link Formatter}
158     *  for each invocation. The implementation here uses a cached instance
159     *  instead, and as {@code Formatter} is not inherently thread-safe, this
160     *  cached instance is created and stored per thread, therefore no
161     *  synchronisation is needed.<br>
162     *  <br>The performance gain for this implementation is not that impressive
163     *  when compared with that of
164     *  {@link #format(String, Object...)},
165     *  but still in the 10% range.
166     *  {@code java.lang.String.format()}.
167     *
168     *  @param  locale  The
169     *      {@link Locale}
170     *      that will be applied during formatting. If {@code locale} is
171     *      {@code null} then no localisation is applied.
172     *  @param  format  A format String with the syntax as described for the
173     *      {@link Formatter}
174     *      class.
175     *  @param  args    The arguments referenced by the format specifiers in
176     *      the {@code format} String. If there are more arguments than format
177     *      specifiers, the extra arguments are ignored. The number of
178     *      arguments is variable and may be zero. The maximum number of
179     *      arguments is limited by the maximum dimension of a Java array as
180     *      defined by <cite>The Java&trade; Virtual Machine
181     *      Specification</cite>. The behaviour on a {@code null} argument
182     *      depends on the conversion.
183     *  @throws IllegalFormatException A format string contains an illegal
184     *      syntax, a format specifier that is incompatible with the given
185     *      arguments, insufficient arguments given the format string, or other
186     *      illegal conditions occurred. For specification of all possible
187     *      formatting errors, see the &quot;Details&quot; section of the
188     *      {@code Formatter} class specification.
189     *  @return A formatted String.
190     *
191     *  @see  java.util.Formatter
192     *
193     *  @since 0.1.0
194     */
195    @API( status = INTERNAL, since = "0.1.0" )
196    public static final String format( final Locale locale, final String format, final Object... args ) throws IllegalFormatException
197    {
198        /*
199         * When this method StringUtils.format() is used inside an
200         * implementation of Formattable.formatTo() that in turn was called by
201         * this method already, the internal out buffer of the formatter
202         * contains already some text that has to be preserved.
203         *
204         * Therefore, the current length of the out buffer is kept before new
205         * contents is added by the call to formatter.format(), and reset after
206         * the new formatted text was retrieved from that buffer.
207         */
208        final var formatter = m_Formatter.get();
209        final var result = (StringBuilder) formatter.out();
210        final var currentPos = result.length();
211        formatter.format( locale, format, args );
212        final var retValue = result.substring( currentPos );
213
214        if( (currentPos == 0) && (result.capacity() > FORMAT_INITIAL_BUFFERSIZE) )
215        {
216            /*
217             * The intention of this code is to reduce the memory  footprint of
218             * the formatter that is mainly determined by the StringBuilder
219             * that is used for the output.
220             */
221            result.setLength( FORMAT_INITIAL_BUFFERSIZE );
222            result.trimToSize();
223        }
224        result.setLength( currentPos );
225
226        //---* Done *----------------------------------------------------------
227        return retValue;
228    }   //  format()
229}
230//  class SharedFormatter
231
232/*
233 *    End of File
234 */
